node.title: We are coming off the wettest November on record. This is what the upcoming La Niña summer has in store
node.description: The east coast is sodden, towns have gone under and summer has only just started. But it will take a lot to beat the  wettest summers.
node.content:
["Soils are sodden,\u00a0towns have already gone under water and summer has only just begun. But how is this year stacking up against the big, wet years?", "La\u00a0Ni\u00f1a is in\u00a0full swing and expected to hang around into the new year. The outlook is for wetter than average conditions to continue for big chunks of the east coast.\u00a0", "Meanwhile, the rest of the country is expecting relatively normal conditions this summer.", "This year has certainly been wet so far but it would take a lot\u00a0to top the record wet summers.\u00a0", "And that's unlikely, says the Bureau of Meteorology, which today\u00a0released it's\u00a0summer outlook:\u00a0", "You don't have to go back far through the history books to get to some pretty impressive La\u00a0Ni\u00f1as seasons.\u00a0", "", "
\"Pretty patchy\". It's been very wet start to summer in many parts of the country -- but not all.(Supplied: Damien Blazer)
", "The two biggest of recent decades were around the summers of 2011 and 1974.\u00a0", "The 2010-11 and 2011-12 La\u00a0Ni\u00f1a double peak\u00a0led to the wettest 24-month period the country has recorded.\u00a0", "", "
In the six months to the end of November 2010 heavy rainfall was widespread. The months that followed brought yet more rain and culminated in the devastating 2011 floods.\u00a0(Supplied: Bureau of Meteorlogy)
", "", "
Rainfall has certainly been heavy in patches over the last six months but it has not been as widespread as in 2010.\u00a0
", "The period between June 1973 and March 1976\u00a0was the longest La\u00a0Ni\u00f1a event on record\u00a0and 1974 is still Australia's wettest year in the history books.\u00a0", "\"This year so far we have had the wettest November on record, but when we think about season and annual rainfall, it's not yet at the same levels as the previous two,\" Associate Professor Andr\u00e9a Taschetto, of\u00a0UNSW Science\u2019s Climate Change Research Centre, said.", "Wetlands are also not as wet.", "Professor Richard Kingsford and his team at the Centre for Ecosystem Science, UNSW, conduct aerial surveys of water birds to gain insights into the health of the river systems.\u00a0\u00a0", "\"We've flown over so much of eastern Australia and it's still pretty patchy,\" Professor Kingsford said.", "That doesn't mean that it can't happen though, with plenty of summer left.\u00a0", "\"We're still in December so we could still see some flooding. Also in the Murray-Darling Basin, the flooding isn't as significant as it was in 2010 or in 1974,\" Professor Kingsford said.", "So are we going to see another record-breaking\u00a0event\u00a0this\u00a0summer?", "\"My answer is: It's too soon to say but we cannot discount it,\"\u00a0Dr Taschetto said.", "
Climate and flood
", "Professor Ashish Sharma of the UNSW School of Civil and Environmental Engineering said climate change meant\u00a0rising temperatures.", "\"As temperatures rise, your atmosphere can store a lot more moisture,\" Professor Sharma said.", "", "
It is relatively moist under foot for the majority of the country.(Supplied: Bureau of Meteorology)
", "But on the other hand, warmer temperatures help dry soil so it can absorb more moisture.\u00a0So in normal or dry\u00a0years, soils help to counter increased rainfall.\u00a0", "But in La\u00a0Ni\u00f1a years\u00a0when soils are already moist, we could\u00a0really get to see the impact of heavier rainfall.\u00a0", "", "
This summer is expected to be wetter than average for parts of the east but relatively normal through the centre.\u00a0\u00a0(Supplied: Bureau of Meteorology)
", "
The good and the bad of floods\u00a0
", "We usually talk about floods in terms of damage but floods can also be a good thing.\u00a0", "", "
Pelicans\u00a0are among the dozens of species benefiting from floodwaters that have made their way down into the Menindee Lakes.(ABC News: Niall Lenihan)
", "\"What we generally find is these La\u00a0Ni\u00f1a\u00a0years are really important in terms of resetting the rivers in terms of their biodiversity,\" Professor Kingsford said.", "\"After the 2010-2011 flood we saw a big bounce back in numbers.\"", "So a good wet year like this one is great for the health of the river systems.\u00a0", "\"The Lachlan flooding, quite a bit down through Forbes, and that's been damaging for some of the towns but it is also very important for the health of that ecosystem,\" he said.\u00a0", "But there is no denying floods bring danger for humans.\u00a0", "It will come as no surprise that summer and school holidays\u00a0are\u00a0peak times for drowning.", "But what should be better known is the risks around rivers and creeks,\u00a0where most drownings happen in Australia.\u00a0", "Dr Amy Peden is the co-founder of the UNSW Beach Safety Research Group.", "Their work has found\u00a070 per cent of all river-related deaths involve flooding.", "According to Dr Peden there were 33 drowning deaths due to the Queensland floods in the 2010-11 summer.", "\"So it is a peak risk time for drowning and that combined with La\u00a0Ni\u00f1a\u00a0and the predicted increased rainfall is adding another layer of concern for us,\" he said.", "
Safety\u00a0tips:
"]
